summary: This 1936 West African Court of Appeal decision addressed two legal questions referred by the Assistant Judge of the Warri Division. First, it confirmed that the Rules of Court established in 1928 under the West African Court of Appeal Order-in-Council applied automatically to Nigeria upon its inclusion in the Court's jurisdiction in 1934, despite changes in rule-making authority. Second, it held that the High Court may entertain a motion for conditional leave to appeal, affirming established litigant practice in the absence of specific procedural rules. The Court rejected both rulings by the Assistant Judge as incorrect, clarifying procedural rights in appellate practice across British West African territories.
topics: Legal Practice in British West Africa
verdict: Both rulings by the Assistant Judge were held to be incorrect.
citations: West African Court of Appeal Order-in-Council, 1928, Art. 12(1)
West African Court of Appeal Ordinance, 1933, s. 3(a) and s. 7
rationaleHighlights: Rules made under valid authority in 1928 applied automatically to Nigeria upon jurisdictional extension in 1934.
No need to remake rules with jurisdictional changes.
Conditional leave motions are procedurally valid in absence of specific rules.
Established litigant practice accepted and approved by appellate court.
High Court has competence to entertain conditional appeal applications.
